Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: Collaborative Research: LAWN: Scaling Up Cellular Data Networks using a Large Number of Antennas

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The exponential growth of mobile data is a major challenge to the operators of cellular networks. Looking beyond conventional capacity-improving approaches such as adding more cells and acquiring more spectrum, this project seeks to fundamentally improve the spectral efficiency of cellular data networks. The project investigates LAWN (Large number of Antenna based Wireless Networking), a radically new cellular network architecture, in which a large number of antennas simultaneously serve a relatively much smaller number of wireless terminals using multiuser beamforming. The project has two inter-related thrusts. The first investigates a novel LAWN base station design and prototype that can cost-effectively scale to hundreds of antennas and exploit physical-layer tradeoffs between computational complexity and network capacity. The second thrust studies the resulting new network architecture that efficiently schedules terminals, intelligently allocates transmission power, and coordinates pilot signal transmissions to mitigate inter-cell interference.

The project targets improving the spectral and power efficiency of cellular networks by many fold, leading to not only fast wireless data networks but also longer battery lifetime of mobile terminals. Results from the project are likely to provide fresh insights for new theoretical development, bringing large-scale multi-user beamforming one significant leap closer to practical deployment in cellular data networks. In addition to academic publications, the project will produce an open platform, including hardware, software, and documentation available on-line, for teaching and researching base station design. It will actively involve undergraduate students as well as students from under-represented populations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The exponential growth of mobile data is a major challenge to the operators of cellular networks. Looking beyond conventional capacity-improving approaches such as adding more cells and acquiring more spectrum, this project seeks to fundamentally improve the spectral efficiency of cellular data networks. The project investigates LAWN (Large number of Antenna based Wireless Networking), a radically new cellular network architecture, in which a base station with a large number of antennas simultaneously serve a smaller number of users concurrently using multi-user multi-input, multi-output (MU-MIMO) technology.  The project had three specific objectives: (i) investigate the feasibility of MU-MIMO base stations with a large number of antennas; (ii) perform measurements using many-antenna MU-MIMO base-station prototypes to tease out the scope under which massive MIMO theoretical results hold; (iii) investigate network implications of the practical results from (i) and (ii).

Toward these objectives, the project developed two generations of prototypes for many-antenna MU-MIMO base stations. Both generations support base-station antennas up to many hundreds and set the world’s record for the number of antennas for which real-time results were reported.  By building the prototypes, the project contributed practical, experimentally validated solutions for channel calibration, distributed baseband computation for conjugate beamforming, and control channel operations that scale up as the number of base-station antennas goes to many hundreds if not thousands. Using the prototypes, the project reported first-of-its-kind measurement results. They showed that the capacity of MIMO base stations grows linearly with regard to M, the number of bases-station antennas, as long as M over the number of users is kept close to 2, demonstrating the theoretical capacity benefit of large MIMO systems is realistic. On the other hand, while massive MIMO theory predicts conjugate beamforming approaches zero-forcing in capacity as M over the number of users approaches infinity, the results showed that significant capacity gap persists even for M=64 and two users. At the same time, the project demonstrated that conjugate beamforming can still beat zero-forcing in real world when computation overhead is considered in an operational system.

The project team presented and published results and demonstrated the base-station prototype at peer-reviewed conferences and workshops as well as industrial events. The outcome of the project added momentum to large-scale MIMO systems, attracting strong interests from both academia and industry: today massive MIMO is considered a key candidate technology for 5G cellular data networks currently under heavy research and development. In particular, this project has influenced Samsung's development of its own 32-antenna MU-MIMO base station prototype and a recent 3GPP's approval of a proposal to study massive MIMO for LTE. The many-antenna base-station prototype serves as the starting point of a recently funded NSF CRI project that aims at building a network testbed of large-scale MIMO base stations. The project provided motivational results and kindled new research collaborations for a recently funded NSF NeTS large grant that aims at laying the practical foundations for large-scale MIMO systems. The project provided research opportunities for multiple graduate students and multiple undergraduate students, which included both women and minorities.
